questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: What layer is the abnormal finding present in?

answers.explanation:
Reticular pseudodrusen are a subtype of drusen in which yellow subretinal lesions are often connected in reticular network and typically start in the supero-temporal macula due to the highest rod photoreceptor density. Compared to typical drusenoid deposits at Bruch’s membrane, reticular drusen carries a higher risk of progression to late age-related macular degeneration, especially geographic atrophy.

​

Large colloidal drusen presents as subretinal material in between the RPE and Bruch’s membrane. Cuticular or basal laminar drusen involves the subretinal structures and will typically demonstrate a ‘starry sky appearance’ on fluorescein angiography. Lastly, laser marks on the retina should be considered if the lesions are distributed in a discrete region of the macula/retina when there is a history of retinal layers (especially if findings are only present in one eye).

answers.answerText: D. Laser marks on the retina

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What are some common associations with reticular pseudodrusen?

answers.answerText: B. Early onset age-related macular degeneration
